Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds the research activities of Professors Eric D'Hoker, Michael Gutperle, and Per Kraus in the Department of Physics and Astronomy at UCLA.

Decades after its discovery, string theory remains a vibrant subject, continuing to shed light on fundamental problems in physics. The basic principles of string theory remain mysterious, as does its precise role in explaining observable physical phenomena, yet its power as a conceptual and computational tool is now well established and being applied to a wide range of topics, from pure mathematics to particle physics and condensed matter. In their research, Professors D'Hoker, Gutperle, and Kraus seek to advance the understanding of the precise formulation of string theory; to shed light on fundamental problems involving black holes and quantum gravity; and to apply techniques of gauge/gravity duality to novel situations in quantum field theory, including those relevant to condensed matter physics.

This project is aimed at having significant broader impact. Professors D'Hoker, Gutperle, and Kraus will be conducting research in a highly collaborative manner involving graduate students and postdocs, thereby providing critical training for physicists in the early stages of their research careers. Professors D'Hoker, Gutperle, and Kraus also plan to disseminate the results of their research by presenting seminars, colloquia, and public lectures, including at high schools and summer schools. Additionally, they are involved in advancing education, outreach, and interdisciplinary collaboration.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Eric D'Hoker (PI), Michael Gutperle (co-PI), Per Kraus (co-PI), and postdoc Simon Gentle have completed a series of research projects in theoretical particle physics, with emphasis on string theory, gauge/gravity duality, black holes, higher spin theories, and applications to various fields of mathematics. 

String theory remains the most promising unification of general relativity and the standard model of particle physics into a theory consistent with quantum mechanics. The dynamics of string theory is highly complex and can be understood quantitatively only in certain limits. A first limit is weakly coupled strings where one outcome of this project consists of the further development of the foundations of superstring perturbation theory and its applications. These results go hand in hand with progress in the theory of supermoduli in mathematics. A second limit in which string theory is reasonably well understood is at low energy and long distances. The outcomes of this project have significantly contributed to understanding better the relation between this limit and the mathematics of automorphic and modular forms. 

Being a theory of gravity, string theory may be applied  to the study of black holes and their thermodynamics. One outcome of this project is the clarification of the effects of higher spin states, which distinguish string theory from ordinary quantum field theory, and their associated symmetries, on the very nature of the geometry of black holes, their event horizon, and their thermodynamics. Another outcome of this project is an improved understanding, and application to concrete examples, of the relation between gauge/gravity duality and entanglement entropy, namely the quantitative characterization of how far a mixed quantum state is from a pure quantum state. In particular, the Ryu-Takayanagi formula connecting entanglement entropy and geometry was tested in geometries with conical defects, interfaces, and string junctions. The PIs have presented much of these results and outcomes during invited lectures at international conferences and workshops throughout the duration of this grant period.

One broader impact outcome of this project has been the professional training and mentoring of graduate students and postdocs. The faculty on this project have routinely co-authored research papers with graduate students and postdocs, organized a weekly journal club in which faculty, postdocs, and students present papers of general interest as well as personal work, and generally helped physicists early on in their careers with practical advice and encouragement. During the course of this project, a one day conference for high school teachers was organized by one PI while the other two PIs organized the Southern California String Seminar once or twice yearly, and delivered classroom lectures and lab demonstrations at two local high schools.
